Greetings! I return from the grave, and such to return to the game known as Neverwinter Nights 1. (I...I haven't played 2 yet. I'm sorta disappointed in myself xD)

Server: Arelith, 30 cap.


Okay, so here's my story. I was playing through (Warning unfamiliar games potentially ahead) Heroes of Might and Magic V and .Hack (Ps2). Going through the motions of playing a commander, and a twin blade each respectively. I ended up fighting for the elven race on heroes, and came across something that hadn't crossed my mind in a while. A twin blade. I thought funnily enough that I might try to build an elven twin blade (two longswords I guess, not sure if anything else is better.) Unfortunately, I couldn't come up with a lot of things. For one, would Dex or Str make more sense? What feats or classes would I need? I know dual wielding feats makes sense. But, I couldn't figure out the specifics. (I know what I want, just not how to go about it.)


My thoughts would be Longswords, unless there's a better alternative. I hear you can dual wield Katanas but unsure if that would be a good idea. I wasn't sure of the skills either. I thought Heal, and trap related things might also be needed (to suppliment the blades) This entire concept of a dual twin blade is kinda foreign to me. The race would be elven.

I was wondering if you all could help? Perhaps, explaining the advantages and cons of a STR or DEX Twinblade (if there even are any. I don't even know if this is a feasible idea, let alone anything else)

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hi Valerionx,

Hope you don't mind if I ask a couple of questions? When you say "twin blade", are you looking to wield two weapons, or one double-sided one? I ask because recommendations might be different depending on that, including whether a STR or DEX-based build would work best (whether Finesse-able shortswords might serve you better, for example). Also, I don't know if Arelith gives an xp penalty when a race strays from its favoured class (for Elf it's Wizard, I believe), or how bothered you'd be about playing with any penalty?

You could go down a Weapon Master route, but that might be problematic in getting all the qualifying feats along with the dual-wielding ones. Pairing it with Fighter would give you more feats to combat that, or Ranger could deal with all the D-W feats (if you took 9 levels in it and didn't wear heavier than Light Armour). And if you want trapping skills, some Rogue might well be worth an investment as well. As you can see, there are many options available, and it would just be helpful if you could offer a few more specifics before those most likely to be of use to you head off in a direction you're not looking for. In other words, a little more on what you want would be helpful, if that's okay?

Cheers

posts.author: hunearo
posts.content:
Longsword counts as a medium weapon, so you get a -4/-4 penalty when dual-wielding them, and cannot be finessed, so str is the only way.
Katana would be better, they are small and can be finessed on arelith, so you could make a dual-katana dexer with only a -2/-2 penalty.

For classes... maybe a fighter-weaponmaster-rogue? Fighter for feats, wm for ab and rogue for skills? Some class preference would be good.

EDIT: haha... ninja'd :D
Btw Stag, afaik there is no xp penalty for multiclassing on arelith.

That's great, thanks. I'm sure better builders than I will be able to provide something suitable. But in the meantime, as far as STR vs DEX is concerned, essentially yes. But, STR builds will, by and large, rely on heavy armour (and maybe a shield) to get their AC up to a level where they're not getting hit in return every round, where a DEXer will have a much better AC by nature, so will be harder to hit regardless of dodging/evading. If they are using Finessed weapons, their DEX bonus will work on their AB like STR does ordinarily, so they'll be hitting just as often as a STR build would - they just wouldn't be dealing as much damage with each strike. Now, Elves get an automatic bonus to their DEX at creation, so that would maybe indicate that's the road to travel, but another way of looking at it is to say: it's easier to get an Elf to a DEX bonus of +1, and so wear all heavy armour without penalty, which then means I could put more points into STR. Personal preference time again!

Again, ignorance of Arelith means I don't know if DevCrit is enabled or not, but it probably says something that the prime target for a STR build will likely be DevCrit - a one-hit kill, whereas Epic Dodge is the commonly accepted holy grail for DEXers. One is offensive, the other defensive, and both require a stat of 25+ in whichever is their prime ability (as well as various feats).

Then, of course, there's Sneak Attack for your Rogue types (or maybe even Crippling Strike in later levels). If you can flank or strike from shadows, your damage increases incrementally with every other level of Rogue you take. Of course, it's a lot harder to sneak about if you're wearing full plate. I'm sure you see where this is going...

In any event, for meleers, the general rule of thumb is "you can't kill it if you can't hit it," so AB is crucial. Dual-wielding therefore creates challenges, because you will suffer an AB hit, whatever weapon(s) you choose. To minimise that, you should take small ones (or at least a small one in your off-hand) to minimize the penalty to -2 (see hunearo's earlier post). That would wipe out the longsword option - regardless of whether STR or DEX based.

So, do you want to be standing before the enemy in your shiny armour, confident of your ability to deal death and mayhem quickly, or take the bastards by surprise when they're looking somewhere else? Your call!

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
OK, Valerionx! Welcome back to NWN. Since you don't seem to know whether you want a str-based toon or a dex-based one, let us get started by outlining the advantages and disadvantages of each one:

STR- the first thing you need to know is that a STR-based dual-wielder will have REALLY LOW AC. Therefore, it won't succeed if it stands toe-to-toe with the enemy. So, if you go STR, I suggest you get Shadowdancer for HiPS. That's the only way you won't die over and over again. My Subtle Death is a good example of one such build. He's a STR-based dual-wielding Assassin. This kind of build does a lot of damage (many attacks per round, lots of STR bonuses to add to them). And if you take classes with Sneak Attack or Death Attack, that's even more damage! However, you also TAKE a lot of damage, so you're bettter off letting someone else in your party do the tanking. If you plan to walk around alone, you might have a hard time staying alive.

DEX- on the opposite side of the damage spectrum, you have AC that will allow you to stand in the pocket, possibly Epic Dodge to dodge the first attack you receive each round (after a long time), and you'll basically pinch your opponent. So your source of damage will have to be probably sneak attacks or weapon buffs, such as Darkfire or Flame Weapon. DEX is also an ability that modifies many good skills, so Rogue or Assassin should be almost a no-brainer (maybe even both).

So basically, STR vs DEX boils down to AC vs Damage. AB, as Stag has already pointed out, will be the same, because of Weapon Finesse (as long as you wield a finesseable weapon).

So, first things first. STR or DEX?

And since we're at it, would you like a spellsword (something with buffs to help you make the transition to the dark side?) or something more of a straight meleer who buffs through consumables?

Oh, and if you're planning to learn how to build, the Game Guides section looks like a good place to start.

Take it EZ!

Empyre65 wrote:
My suggestion is a DEX-based Rogue 16 / Fighter 4 / CoT 10.

I have made the build, but I will post it only if you ask because the goal is to teach you how to make a build for yourself.
Oh, now that sounds like an excellent option for classes and split. Maybe I got too swept up in thinking Weapon Master, particularly in a non DevCrit environment. Your suggestion would negate the necessity of taking essentially redundant feats, increase the number of feats and give saves a much-needed boost. What do you reckon, Valerionx?

If you're okay with it, the first things we'll then have to consider are the vital statistics (and I believe you have this "gift" thing in Arelith to factor in there as well) and pre-Epic AB versus getting Epic Dodge asap (given that we'll need at least 13 levels of Rogue - to get Improved Evasion and Defensive Roll, 30 points in Tumble, and DEX of at least 25 before the feat becomes available. So level 27 at the earliest). Given the class split, I can't see us not losing at least 2 AB pre-Epic, but I wouldn't really want to lose any more than that in a melee build - particularly a D-W one. Maybe a way of striking a balance would be to take the first 4 levels as Rogue, then 4 as Fighter (we'd need that many before CoT becomes available), then work out when to take 4 more Rogue levels and 8 of CoT - giving us a Rogue 8/Fighter 4/CoT 8 pre-Epic split, and a BAB of 18. That would mean Rogue 8/CoT 2 in Epic, and a final BAB of 23.

How does that strike you as a first thought, Valerionx?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I've had a few more thoughts about constructing the build Empyre suggests, but I don't really want to get too deep into it before getting your agreement, Valerionx. Although I can certainly see us getting ED at level 27 and Crippling Strike at level 30. I've reckoned on 14 pre-Epic feats/bonus feats, of which 10 are pretty much must-haves, with 8 others in mind as should/could-haves. And 5 in Epic (4 feats and 1 CoT bonus feat, as well as 3 Rogue-specific bonus feats). I also think we have 246 skill points to allocate, assuming a starting INT of 14.

I also need to ask a few Arelith questions, if that's okay? How many "gifts" would an Elven Rogue get at creation (major and/or minor)? I ask because it could impact on character vitals, skill distribution and feats in Epic levels. I notice that Fighter gets +1 Discipline every 3 levels: is that regardless of anything else? Would taking a background as Wild Child be beneficial? And if so, would the +1s in Tumble, Hide and Move Silently count as modifiers or input skills (so, would we only need to take 29 ranks in Tumble rather than 30 for both the AC and Epic Dodge?). And this katana thing: I'm still unclear as to whether it is now both a light weapon and finesseable, or merely finesseable? It makes a difference - and will also determine whether we need to take WProf:Exotic or not.

Oh, and I recognise that it's 3 levels in a row, rather than 4: so I'd now probably start with 3 Rogue levels, then 3 Fighter, then 1 more Rogue and 1 more Fighter before breaking into CoT at level 9.

Hope this makes sense. I'll leave it with you for now...
